know_passage: The National Restaurant Association stated: “As businesses struggle to recover from the economic recession, dramatic, mandatory wage increases would place yet another financial burden on business owners, potentially worsening living standards for low-income workers. Many restaurateurs would be forced to limit hiring, increase prices, cut employee hours, or implement a combination of all three to pay for the wage increase, which fails to effectively address inequality. According to National Restaurant Association research, 58 percent of restaurant operators increased menu prices and 41 percent reduced employee hours following the 2007 minimum wage increase. These changes often fuel inflation, making the cost of living higher for all consumers.” National Restaurant Association, “Minimum Wage,” available from restaurant.org (accessed Feb. 11, 2016)

know_passage: Cost of living varies wildly in the United States. For example, living in New York, California, and Hawaii costs significantly more than living in Mississippi, Kansas, or Montana. This wage disparity further exacerbates economic inequality across the nation. If the federal government raises the minimum wage significantly, it could lead to job losses as employers, especially in lower-income states, may not afford the increased costs of paying employees. Small businesses in these rural communities would be particularly hard-hit, struggling to survive amidst such financial pressures.

passage_ori: Cost of living varies wildly in the United States. For example, living in New York, California, and Hawaii costs significantly more than living in Mississippi, Kansas, or Montana. If the federal government raises the minimum wage significantly, the wage will be proportionately much higher in lower income states, meaning employers will not be able to afford the costs of paying employees and residents will not be able to afford the cost of living increases necessary to make up the difference. Small rural communities would especially suffer from the disparity. [70][71]

know_passage: Brittany Hunter, Associate Editor at the Foundation for Economic Education (FEE), in a Jan. 12, 2017 article for medium.com titled “What Puerto Rico Can Teach Us about Raising the Minimum Wage,” wrote: “When the minimum wage is increased, the private sector is responsible for finding the means to actually pay for these increases. Though many companies will be forced to raise prices in order to continue operating within their profit margins, some might be left with no option but to terminate employees or significantly reduce employee hours. Since minimum wage pay is typically associated with entry-level workers, if employers are forced to let these employees go, they will lack the skills necessary to quickly rebound in the job market. As a result, the unemployment rate begins to rise, further exacerbating inequality and deteriorating living standards for vulnerable workers.” Brittany Hunter, “What Puerto Rico Can Teach Us about Raising the Minimum Wage,” medium.com, Jan. 12, 2017. Rising wages can lead to increased inflation, further burdening consumers.
